monogr.title: The golden fleece : diuided into three parts, vnder which are discouered the errours of religion, the vices and decayes of the kingdome, and lastly the wayes to get wealth, and to restore trading so much complayned of. Transported from Cambrioll Colchos, out of the southermost part of the iland, commonly called the Newfoundland, by Orpheus Iunior, for the generall and perpetuall good of Great Britaine
monogr.author: Vaughan, William
monogr.extent: 28, 149, 1, 105, 1, 96 pages, 1 folded leaf of plates, map, 4°

keywords.term: Travel, topography, maps and navigational manuals

div.head: In Honour of the Golden Fleece described by Orpheus Iunior.
div.l: O How my heart doth leape with Ioy to heare,
Our New-found Ile by Britaines prized deare!
That hopefull Land, which Winters sixe I tri'd,
And for our Profit meet, at full descri'd.
If Hope of Fame, of quiet Life, or Gaine
May kindle Flames within our minds againe:
Then let vs ioyne to seeke this Golden Fleece,
The like ne're came from Colchos into Greece.
Orphens remoues all Errours from the way,
And how this Land shall thriue, he doth bewray.
Thus ships & coine increase, whē least we thought,
For Fish and Traines Exchange, and all vnbought,
